Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: The line at the register snakes around the corner, and the beeping of scanned items is relentless. My manager’s words echo in my mind: “Stay cheerful, no matter what.” The woman in front of me slams her groceries on the belt, her voice sharp and impatient. I force a smile, swallowing my frustration, reminding myself that as a cashier, I’m expected to be the calm in the storm, especially during the holiday rush. But my thoughts keep drifting to the envelope of savings tucked away at home, the one I’ve guarded for years, meant for Hajj. My friends are going this season, sending me photos of their preparations, their excitement infectious. I feel the weight of my faith, the longing to fulfill this pillar of Islam, pressing against the demands of my job. If I take time off now, I risk losing my position, maybe even dipping into my Hajj savings to cover lost wages. The customer’s glare snaps me back. I apologize, my voice trembling, caught between the expectations of my faith and the reality of my work. My heart aches with the impossible choice looming before me.
